item.title: Covid-19: No limit on funeral mourners in England from 17 May
item.description: The government is preparing to remove the 30-person legal limit a month earlier than planned.

item.title: Gyms open and friends hug as rules relax in Wales
item.description: Some families and friends can hug again as Covid rules continue to be relaxed.

item.title: Coronavirus: Why some mosques are closed to women during Ramadan
item.description: Ramadan is marked by Muslims worldwide - but some UK mosques aren't letting women in.

item.title: NI 100: 'Peace in Northern Ireland is credit to people'
item.description: Queen Elizabeth marks centenary of Northern Ireland with tribute to people and peace process.

item.title: Line of Duty finale lands record ratings
item.description: An average audience of 12.8 million viewers tune into the final episode of the drama's sixth series.

item.title: Four held in German-led raid on huge child sexual abuse network
item.description: German police say a dark web club for sharing images of child sex abuse had more than 400,000 users.

item.title: Apetamin: Instagram criticised over weight gain drug
item.description: NHS England calls for a clamp down on the targeting of the "dangerous" unlicensed drug at young women.

item.title: Billie Eilish: Sexual misconduct is everywhere
item.description: The singer-songwriter discusses sexual impropriety and body image as she unveils new look in Vogue.

item.title: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe: UK and Iran in talks over debt but 'unlinked' to case
item.description: But the debt negotiations are not linked to Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe's case, James Cleverly says.

item.title: G7: Rich states want to send 40m more girls to school
item.description: Foreign ministers at a London summit pledge $15bn (£10.8bn) to help women in developing countries.

item.title: Vax Live: Prince Harry makes vaccine plea at concert in LA
item.description: The Duke of Sussex appears with Jennifer Lopez and President Biden at a star-studded charity show.

item.title: Why can't Google get a grip on rip-off ads?
item.description: Shyster websites topped the search results every time during a 12-month BBC investigation.

item.title: Trees planted by hospital treating Covid patient
item.description: Staff from a Cardiff intensive care unit are offsetting the environmental impact of treating patients.

item.title: The Papers: 'Fever pitch' at Old Trafford
item.description: Monday's front pages focus on protests at Manchester United's ground, and social distancing rules.

item.title: Shearer and Jenas on Man Utd fans' protest
item.description: Match of the Day 2 pundits Alan Shearer and Jermaine Jenas discuss the protests against the Glazer family which led to the postponement of Manchester United's game against Liverpool.

item.title: Brazil: Vaccinating the Amazon against Covid
item.description: The BBC follows healthcare workers in Brazil's Amazon region delivering vaccines to one of the most isolated parts of a vast country.

item.title: Walrus in Wales: How did Wally end up in Tenby?
item.description: Is Wally the walrus really in Wales looking for somewhere new for lunch?

item.title: Huawei Mate X2: Mastering the folding phone formula
item.description: Huawei has revealed the third iteration of its folding phone, taking inspiration from Samsung.

item.title: Kyrgyzstan-Tajikistan: Images of destruction after border clashes
item.description: At least 46 people were killed while homes, schools and checkpoints were destroyed in the dispute.

item.title: SpaceX ISS mission: Night-time splashdown for four astronauts
item.description: Four astronauts splash down off the coast of Florida after a six-month mission to the International Space Station.

item.title: Walton-on-the-Naze: 'People are almost panic buying beach huts'
item.description: Beach huts have never been so in demand in an Essex seaside town - what's all the fuss about?

item.title: Sweden's IVF programme for single women not 'as good as hoped'
item.description: In 2016, single women in the country were given the same rights as couples to access fertility treatments.

item.title: India Covid: Delhi hospitals plead for oxygen as more patients die
item.description: Desperate messages continued on Sunday night as Delhi's oxygen crisis shows no signs of abating.

item.title: Covid: Packed pilot festival brings the good times back - for one night
item.description: Blossoms play to 5,000 fans in Liverpool to help gather research for this summer's festival season.

item.title: A £455m debt and the ESL: Man Utd protests explained
item.description: Protests at Manchester United's Old Trafford ground came just weeks after European Super League plans were thwarted - but emotions have been simmering for 16 years.

item.title: Sarah Halimi: How killer on drugs escaped French trial for anti-Semitic murder
item.description: The decision not to prosecute a Jewish woman's killer because of his drug use sparks a legal row in France.

item.title: NI 100: Tracing the history of the 100-year-old Irish border
item.description: On May 3 1921 Northern Ireland came into being as the partition of Ireland took legal effect.

item.title: My Money: 'It feels like a luxury to shop for non-essential items'
item.description: Social care worker Sarah takes us through her weekly spending as England's national lockdown lifts.

item.title: 'I was terrible at crosswords so I built an AI to do them'
item.description: Dr Fill , a computer program, has just won one of the most prestigious crossword competitions in the US.

item.title: Carbon: How calls for climate justice are shaking the world
item.description: Young activists are breathing new life into the long-running debate over how to cut carbon fairly.

item.title: 'More and more people don't want a traditional burial'
item.description: With cremations on the rise, firms now offer such things as turning your ashes into artificial reef formations or human compost.

item.title: The young woman trying to adopt her friend
item.description: Arina hopes to formally adopt her friend Nina, whom she looked after during the Covid pandemic.

item.title: Charity shops: Six things to check before you drop off your old stuff
item.description: "We don't want your dirty pants" - charity shops are asking people to call before donating, but why?

item.title: World Snooker Championship: Mark Selby delivers vintage display to lead Shaun Murphy
item.description: Mark Selby delivers a vintage display to come from behind to open up a three-frame lead against Shaun Murphy in the World Championship final

item.title: Kolkata Knight Riders v Royal Challengers Bangalore postponed over Covid cases
item.description: Monday's Indian Premier League match between Kolkata Knight Riders and Royal Challengers Bangalore is postponed after two KKR players test positive for Covid-19.

item.title: How Lukaku's resurgence fired Inter to first Serie A title for 11 years
item.description: BBC Sport looks at Belgium striker Romelu Lukaku's importance in Inter Milan's first Serie A title in 11 years.

item.title: 'I almost can't let the tears go' - Hayes overwhelmed as Chelsea reach Champions League final
item.description: Boss Emma Hayes is "overwhelmed" and struggling to express her pride at taking Chelsea to a first Women's Champions League final.

item.title: GB women win 4x400m bronze at World Athletics Relays
item.description: Great Britain's 4x400m women's team claim bronze at the 2021 World Athletics Relays event in Silesia in Poland.

item.title: 2021 elections: A simple guide to the Scottish, Welsh and local elections
item.description: A bumper crop of elections are being held on 6 May across England, Scotland and Wales.

item.title: 2021 elections: What elections can I vote in this year?
item.description: National elections in Scotland and Wales and local elections in England are scheduled for 6 May 2021.

item.title: Wales election 2021: Who should I vote for? Compare party policies
item.description: Compare where the parties stand on key issues - from Covid-19 and the NHS to education and the environment.

item.title: Shaun Bailey: 'Politics isn't scary when you've seen stabbings'
item.description: Shaun Bailey says having grown up poor and been homeless in London, politics does not phase him.

item.title: Elections 2021: Why a lack of buses is a key issue for voters
item.description: Infrequent buses and cancelled services - why public transport is a vital topic for young voters.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go.... and who with?
item.description: The rules on having a holiday in the UK have been relaxed - but restrictions remain.

item.title: Rare blood clots - what you need to know
item.description: We take a look at why these unusual clots happen and when they occur.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People 40 or over in England are now being offered a Covid vaccine as the rollout continues.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: Covid: Is Europe lifting lockdown restrictions?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?
